sen.j: 足利氏の一門である細川氏は、南朝 (日本)との戦いでは北朝を擁する足利幕府に従い、足利家の内紛である観応の擾乱では征夷大将軍足利尊氏に属する。
sen.e: The Hosokawa clan was one family within the Ashikaga clan and during the battles with the Nan-cho (Southern Dynasty in Japan) was ordered by the Ashikaga Shogunate to support the Hoku-cho (Northern Dynasty). Was associated with Takauji ASHIKAGA, the seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") during Kanno no Joran (internal conflict of Kanno) and Ashikaga clan internal struggles.

The Hosokawa clan was one family within the Ashikaga clan and, during the battles with the Nan-cho (Southern Court in Japan), was ordered by the Ashikaga Shogunate to support the Hoku-cho (Northern Court). In the Kanno no Joran (internal conflict of Kanno), which was an internal struggle within the Ashikaga clan, the Hosokawas sided with Takauji ASHIKAGA, the seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").
sen.cmt: Changed second sentence. Also, in all the other documents I have checked, Nan-cho and Boku-cho are translated as Northern Court and Southern Court. Also at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Court
sen.e: The Hosokawa clan was one family within the Ashikaga clan and, during the battles with the Southern Court, was ordered by the Ashikaga Shogunate to support the Northern Court; in Kanno Disturbance, which was an internal struggle within the Ashikaga clan, the Hosokawas sided with Takauji ASHIKAGA, the seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").
sen.cmt: 説明が前出のため、the Nan-cho (Southern Court in Japan)をthe Southern Courtとしました。同じくHoku-cho ()削除しました。一原文一訳文の原則に従って、一文に訂正しました。Kanno Disturbanceとしました。

sen.e: His father, Kazuuji died in 1342 and Kiyoji was directed by his uncle, Yoriharu HOSOKAWA to fight for the Nan-cho (Southern Dynasty) and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 清氏は寺社勢力や公家の反対を押し切り、分国の若狭において半済を強行するなど強引な行動も多く、幕政では分国を巡る争いのあった斯波氏や、同格の仁木義長らの政敵も多かった。
sen.e: Kiyouji overcame opposition to the nobility and the influence of temples and shrines. In Wakasa province there were many instances of coersion such as forcing payment of Hanzei (fief taxes). The Shogunate had to address many fief related disputes involving the Shiba clan and political opponents of similar standing such as Yoshinaga NIKI.

In September 1361 whilst Kiyouji was absent, the Shogun Yoshiakira turned to Emperor Go-kogon to hunt down and kill Kiyouji. Kiyouji makes good an escape to Wakasa province together with his younger brothers Yorikazu and Nobuuji.

sen.j: 清氏は讃岐へ移り、義詮から清氏追討を命じられた阿波守護で、清氏の従弟にあたる細川頼之に対しては、小豆島の佐々木信胤や塩飽諸島の塩飽水軍などを味方に付けて海上封鎖を行い、白峰城（高屋城とも、現香川県綾歌郡宇多津町、坂出市）を本拠に宇多津の頼之勢と戦う。
sen.e: Kiyouji moved to the Sanuki area where Yoshiakira ordered the Awa region shugo (military governor) to hunt down and kill Kiyouji. However, with Kiyouji`s cousin; Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, and an alliance with Nobutane SASAKI of Shodo-shima Island and the Shiwaku marines of the Shiwaku-shoto Island Chain a sea-blockade was set up and battles ensued in the strongholds of Shiramine Castle together with Takaya Castle (present day Sakaide City and Utazu-cho Ayauta-gun, Kagawa Prefecture) with Yoriyuki`s military forces.

Kiyouji moved to the Sanuki area and Yoshiakira ordered Kiyouji's cousin Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, who was shugo (military governor) of Awa Province to hunt down and kill him. However, Kiyouji made alliances with Nobutane SASAKI of Shodo-shima Island and the Shiwaku marines of the Shiwaku-shoto Island Chain, set up a sea-blockade and fought Yoriyuki using Shiramine Castle and Takaya Castle (present day Sakaide City and Utazu-cho Ayauta-gun, Kagawa Prefecture) as bases.
